TITLE I--TEACHER STABILIZATION

SEC. 101. GRANTS AUTHORIZED.

The Secretary of Education shall provide grants to States to prevent teacher layoffs and support the creation of additional jobs in public schools. The Secretary reserves funds for outlying areas, Bureau of Indian Education schools, and administration. State awards are based on a percentage of remaining funds. The Secretary allocates funds to each State based on population ratios for individuals aged 5 through 17 and total population. If a State does not receive a grant, the funds are reallocated to other States using a specific formula. SEC. 103. STATE APPLICATION. State chief executives must submit an application to the Secretary within 30 days of this Act's enactment to request a grant, ensuring maintenance of support for education at or above 2011 levels for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. Those not seeking a grant must submit a letter to the Secretary within the same timeframe. The State chief executive must submit a letter to the Secretary within 30 days of the Act's enactment if they do not wish to receive a grant under this title. The Secretary may waive the assurance requirement for a State under certain circumstances such as natural disasters or a significant decline in financial resources. SEC. 104. STATE GRANTS. Each State receiving a grant under this title must reserve a portion for State-funded early learning programs and administrative costs. The remaining funds are to be used for awards to local educational agencies for early childhood, elementary, and secondary public education, distributed based on enrollment ratios. The State must allocate grant funds to local educational agencies based on enrollment ratios. A State receiving a grant must distribute subgrants to local educational agencies within 100 days. The State must distribute grant funds to local educational agencies based on enrollment ratios within 100 days. Grant funds cannot be used to establish or supplement rainy-day funds, supplant State funds, or reduce debt obligations. SEC. 105 and SEC. 106 outline the permitted uses of funds for local educational agencies and state-funded early learning programs, respectively. Funds can be used for compensation, benefits, and expenses related to retaining, recalling, or hiring employees to provide educational services. Both entities must obligate the funds by September 30, 2014. SEC. 107 pertains to reporting requirements. SEC. 107 requires States receiving grants to report on fund usage and job support by September 30 of 2013 and 2014. SEC. 108 provides definitions for terms used in the title. SEC. 109 authorizes appropriations. SEC. 109 authorizes $30 billion for the grant program in fiscal years 2012 and 2013. TITLE II aims to prevent layoffs and create jobs for law enforcement officers and firefighters through funding to States and localities. The title aims to provide funds to prevent layoffs and create jobs for law enforcement officers and firefighters. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to make competitive grants for hiring, rehiring, and retaining firefighters. $1 billion is authorized for each fiscal year 2012 and 2013, with a portion reserved for administrative costs. SEC. 203. LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICER GRANT PROGRAM. The Attorney General will make competitive grants to hire, rehire, and retain law enforcement officers. $4 billion is authorized for fiscal years 2012 and 2013, with a portion reserved for administrative costs.
